dialog.line: Afternoon Janice, what can I get you?
Just the evening paper thanks, oh, and a pint of milk.
You're a governor up at that school now aren't you?
Have you got five minutes? I wanted to ask you something...
Yes it's fine, I'm not in a hurry.

Well, I hope I'm not speaking out of place and I don't really know if you are the person to talk to but. Well, let me get to the point. Earlier on this afternoon two girls came into the shop from your school and, well, to put it simply one girl was making the other girl buy her stuff. They tried to buy cigarettes at first but I wasn't having any of that, they didn't look sixteen to me, so then they just brought some sweets. But the thing is Janice the girl who was spending the money looked scared stiff.
Are you sure they were from Greenham Secondary?
Yes. They had the same uniform on that our Katie wears.

I didn't get the stroppy one but she called the blond one Emma. I reckon the scared kid was Jason Green's daughter. So what do you think? Can the school do anything about this even though it didn't happen at school?
Well, for a start I think it's pretty unlikely that if bullying were going on it would stop the minute they got into school, but by law we aren't actually responsible for what happens out of school.
Not responsible? You mean the teachers don't want the hassle!

No, that's really not true. The school would like to be able to take action because, as I say, bullying outside school always means trouble inside the school as well. But if we did, any parent has the law on their side because we don't have the power.
What do you think? We tell the police? I mean, extortion is a crime.

Well, we can't really do that without Emma coming forward. And I don't really know what proof we have that would enable us to go marching up to her house saying she's being bullied. It really is a hard one. Emma probably wouldn't want us to do anything or else she would have told the school by now. I'll check the anti-bullying policy, there must be something we can do.
But Janice, that's a bit naive. Maybe she's just scared.
These things are difficult, but sometimes there just isn't an answer. Just let me think about it, ok?
